course_metadata.title: Business Agility Foundations (ICP-BAF)
course_metadata.subtitle: Agile Practices and Methodologies for Organizational Agility
course_metadata.target_audience: Marketing Professionals, HR Professionals, Finance Professionals, Salespeople, Executives, Team Leads, Directors, Managers - enterprise business context
course_metadata.duration: 14 hours (2-day intensive or spread over multiple sessions)
prerequisites: Openness to new ways of thinking and working

course_objectives: Develop an agile mindset and articulate agile practices that support business agility
Define and deliver customer value while adapting to change and emerging opportunities
Apply agile methodologies, tools, and techniques in enterprise business contexts (marketing, HR, finance, etc.)
Create action plans to implement business agility practices in their organizations

modules.module_description: Set the foundation for understanding business agility including VUCA environment drivers, core values and principles, and the compelling case for organizational change
module_objectives: Understand why business agility is critical in today's VUCA environment
Articulate the values and principles that enable organizational intelligence
Recognize the critical success factors for agile teams and organizations

sections.section_description: Understanding VUCA and why business agility is critical for success
learning_objectives: Illustrate the core foundational concepts of Business Agility in relevant business contexts (marketing, HR, finance, sales)
Explain how VUCA (Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity, Ambiguity) impacts organizations
Identify why business agility is a competitive advantage
assessment_opportunities: formative: Group discussion on VUCA challenges in participants' organizations
common_misconceptions: Business agility is only for IT or software development teams

sections.section_title: Values, Principles, and Dimensions of Business Agility
sections.section_description: Core values and principles that enable persistent business agility
learning_objectives: Clarify values and principles and why they are important enablers of building organizational intelligence
Describe the role of values and principles in cultivating new ways of thinking and working
Identify how these values apply in different business functions

sections.section_description: Understanding empowered teams, customer value, and continuous learning
learning_objectives: Convey that critical success factors include trust, safety, collaboration, cohesion, autonomy, mastery and purpose
Grasp why and how to shift focus from outputs to outcomes
Communicate why creating disruptive outcomes requires real-time knowledge generation and new ways of working
assessment_opportunities: formative: Outputs vs outcomes identification exercise
common_misconceptions: Empowered teams mean no accountability or structure

module_assessment.description: Reflect on the case for change in participants' own organizational contexts

supplementary: Case studies of agile transformations in non-IT functions

modules.module_description: Develop an agile mindset by exploring growth mindset, mental models, complexity, and polarities. Run the Team Alignment Canvas activity to align teams around purpose and ways of working.
module_objectives: Develop a growth mindset and recognize blind spots and mental models
Understand complexity and how to manage polarities effectively
Align teams around shared purpose, values, and ways of working using the Team Alignment Canvas

sections.section_description: Understanding and cultivating a growth mindset as foundation for business agility
learning_objectives: Describe the attributes of a growth mindset in contrast to the limitations of a fixed mindset
Introduce the concept of reframing failure as an opportunity to learn
Apply growth mindset principles to business challenges
common_misconceptions: Growth mindset means everything is easy with enough effort

sections.section_title: Mental Models, Blind Spots, and Sense Making
sections.section_description: Recognizing how our mental models shape perceptions and identifying blind spots
learning_objectives: Recognize that blind spots and mental biases exist and understand their role
Apply the skills needed to examine mental models and how individuals make meaning
Identify personal mental models that may constrain agility
common_misconceptions: Mental models are unchangeable
Only others have blind spots

sections.section_description: Understanding complex adaptive systems and their implications for management
learning_objectives: Provide an overview of complex adaptive systems and complexity theory
Provide practical awareness of relevant management models (Cynefin, Theory of Constraints, Systems Dynamics)
Distinguish between complicated and complex contexts
common_misconceptions: Complex problems can be solved with detailed plans
All business problems are complex

sections.section_description: Distinguishing polarities from problems and learning both/and thinking
learning_objectives: Distinguish polarities (dilemmas, paradoxes) from traditional problems
Learn to see the relationship between poles to optimize wins and minimize losses
Practice both/and vs either/or thinking
common_misconceptions: All problems can and should be solved
Polarities mean compromise and lose-lose

sections.section_description: Hands-on activity to align teams around purpose, values, and ways of working
learning_objectives: Facilitate team alignment around shared purpose and values
Create clarity on roles, responsibilities, and ways of working
Establish team norms and expectations collaboratively

module_assessment.description: Team Alignment Canvas activity and reflection on insights gained

required: Team Alignment Canvas template (printed or digital)
supplementary: Carol Dweck's research on growth mindset
Cynefin framework resources by Dave Snowden

modules.module_description: Create compelling visions and strategic clarity while developing customer empathy. Run the Foundations Sprint activity (Basics > Differentiation > Magic Lenses) to help teams focus on what matters most.
module_objectives: Communicate the importance of compelling visions and clarity of purpose
Develop customer empathy using various tools and techniques
Apply Foundations Sprint methodology to create strategic focus

sections.section_title: Compelling Vision and Clarity of Purpose
sections.section_description: Creating visions that inspire and align organizations
learning_objectives: Communicate the importance of aligning organizations around a crisp, believable, compelling and inspiring vision
Experience methods for creating such visions and clear purposes
Articulate vision in ways that engage and motivate teams
common_misconceptions: Vision is just a marketing statement
Vision doesn't matter for day-to-day work

sections.section_description: Understanding customers, stakeholders, and how to deliver differentiating value
learning_objectives: Explain the values, principles, tools and techniques needed to develop empathy and improve customer awareness
Apply tools such as persona maps, customer journey maps, empathy maps, customer value propositions
Recognize that everyone between you and the customer is an internal customer
common_misconceptions: Only customer-facing roles need customer empathy
Value is objective and universal

sections.section_description: Looking backwards from a desired future to identify the path forward
learning_objectives: Envision the future state of business agility
Learn ways to look backwards from that future to craft a compelling path
Gain understanding of why and how to use this activity with teams
common_misconceptions: The future is too uncertain to envision
Vision should be created by leadership only

sections.section_title: Activity: Foundations Sprint (Basics > Differentiation > Magic Lenses)
sections.section_description: Hands-on activity to help teams focus strategically using a three-phase approach
learning_objectives: Apply the Foundations Sprint methodology to identify basics, differentiators, and magic lenses
Prioritize what matters most for strategic focus
Create clarity on where to invest time and resources
common_misconceptions: Everything is equally important
Magic lenses are just nice-to-haves

module_assessment.description: Foundations Sprint activity completion and strategic priorities presentation

modules.module_description: Learn to make value visible, ask powerful questions, design experiments, and navigate change. Run assumptions mapping and experiment design activities.
module_objectives: Apply high-performance questions and make value visible
Design and run experiments using hypothesis testing
Navigate change dynamics and co-create sustainable change

sections.section_description: Using powerful questions to enable business agility
learning_objectives: Define high-performance questions and give examples of their power
Discuss techniques for using them in day-to-day conversations
Practice asking vs telling
common_misconceptions: Questions are for when you don't have answers
Telling is faster and more efficient than asking

sections.section_description: Understanding what value really means and how to make it transparent
learning_objectives: Emphasize that value is only delivered through completed work delivered to customers
Identify marginal, negative, and non-value tasks
Practice making value visible in workflows
assessment_opportunities: formative: Value vs non-value activity classification
common_misconceptions: Being busy means creating value
All work is valuable

sections.section_description: Learning to run rapid experiments and test assumptions
learning_objectives: Understand why and how to identify small, discrete opportunities
Craft hypotheses to frame relevant experiments
Understand why rapid experimentation accelerates learning and business agility
common_misconceptions: Experiments must be large-scale to be valid
Failure is bad

sections.section_title: Activity: Assumptions Mapping and Experiment Design
sections.section_description: Hands-on activity to map assumptions and design a test & learn experiment
learning_objectives: Map assumptions underlying a business opportunity or initiative
Prioritize riskiest assumptions to test first
Design a lean experiment to test key assumptions
common_misconceptions: We know all our assumptions
Experiments take too long

sections.section_description: Understanding why change is hard and how to co-create sustainable change
learning_objectives: Experience the complex dynamics involved in creating sustainable change
Understand lean change practices and why co-creating change is essential
Describe change frameworks and what makes them effective
common_misconceptions: Change can be mandated top-down
Resistance is always bad

module_assessment.description: Assumptions mapping and experiment design activity with team presentations

supplementary: Testing Business Ideas by Bland & Osterwalder

modules.module_description: Learn about lean systems thinking, lean startup, design thinking, Kanban, and iterative frameworks. Design your Kanban workflow to optimize for flow and value delivery.
module_objectives: Understand lean systems thinking and how it enables business agility
Apply concepts from lean startup, design thinking, and Kanban
Design a Kanban workflow optimized for your team's context

sections.section_description: Understanding end-to-end systems thinking and focus on value
learning_objectives: Learn why lack of systems thinking leads to waste and ineffective outcomes
Understand how Lean Systems Approach enables business agility
Apply systems thinking to identify waste and optimize value flow
assessment_opportunities: formative: Waste identification in sample process
common_misconceptions: Optimizing individual parts optimizes the whole
Systems thinking is too complex for everyday use

sections.section_description: Build-Measure-Learn framework and human-centered design approaches
learning_objectives: Introduce concepts and applications of the Build-Measure-Learn framework
Learn about MVP, thin slices, and failing fast to succeed sooner
Apply design thinking concepts focused on people, technology, and business
common_misconceptions: MVP means minimum quality
Design thinking is only for designers

sections.section_description: Understanding Kanban values, principles, and practices
learning_objectives: Provide understanding of key Kanban values: understanding, agreement, respect, leadership, flow, customer focus, transparency, balance, collaboration
Understand the 4 key practices: visualize workflow, lead using team approach, limit WIP, learn and improve continuously
Apply Kanban principles to optimize work flow
common_misconceptions: Kanban is just a board with sticky notes
Kanban means no planning

sections.section_description: Understanding iterative frameworks and how they accelerate learning
learning_objectives: Understand iterative frameworks and how they accelerate learning and discovery
Recognize the value of frequent feedback and delivery cycles
Compare and contrast different iterative approaches including Scrum basics
common_misconceptions: Iterations mean rework and waste
You must follow frameworks exactly

sections.section_description: Hands-on activity to design a Kanban workflow optimized for your team
learning_objectives: Design a Kanban board that visualizes your team's workflow
Identify appropriate work stages and WIP limits
Create workflow policies and continuous improvement practices
assessment_opportunities: formative: Team presentations and peer feedback
common_misconceptions: One Kanban design fits all contexts
The board is the goal rather than improved flow

module_assessment.description: Kanban workflow design activity with team presentations and peer feedback

supplementary: Kanban: Successful Evolutionary Change by David Anderson
The Lean Startup by Eric Ries

modules.module_description: Synthesize learning, create action plans for applying business agility, and commit to continuous reinvention and learning
module_objectives: Synthesize key learnings from the course
Create actionable plans to apply business agility in participants' contexts
Commit to ongoing application and continuous learning

sections.section_title: Creating Space for Optimal Engagement and Action Planning
sections.section_description: Reflecting on learning and creating action plans for ongoing application
learning_objectives: Analyze what a business agility environment and learning ecosystem looks like
Devise strategies to create an environment that enables value creation and rapid decision making
Reflect on and synthesize key learnings in participants' unique contexts
Create personal action plans to extend Business Agility mastery beyond the course
common_misconceptions: Learning ends when the course ends
I need to implement everything at once

sections.section_description: Business agility as an ongoing journey, not a destination
learning_objectives: Identify and explain ways to make ongoing application of business agility habitual
Communicate the importance of learning agility and empirical data
Understand limitations of lagging indicators and importance of leading indicators and metrics that matter
assessment_opportunities: formative: Verbal commitment to next steps
common_misconceptions: Success can be measured with traditional metrics only
More metrics are always better

module_assessment.description: Personal action plan and commitment to ongoing learning

overall_assessment.passing_criteria: Active participation in all activities, completion of action plan, and demonstration of understanding through discussions
overall_assessment.assessment_philosophy: Emphasizes experiential learning, practical application, and commitment to ongoing development rather than traditional testing

recommended_readings: The Lean Startup by Eric Ries

notes: Course designed for in-person delivery over 2 full days or 4 half-days
Emphasizes enterprise business context with examples relevant to marketing, HR, finance, sales functions
Heavy focus on hands-on activities and experiential learning
Can be adapted for virtual delivery with appropriate breakout room activities
All activities should be contextualized to participants' actual work challenges
Facilitator should have examples from non-IT business contexts ready
Materials should include ICAgile branding and learning outcomes attribution
